anchor.surface_text: In the enquiry held by the Collector of Ghazipore into the proprietary right claimed by the jagirdar under Regulation 11 of 1819,

issues.text: whether the right of the respondent to receive the allowance under the arrangement of the year 1838 was extinguished as a consequence ensuing from the vesting of the Sudpore Bhettree parganas in the State of Uttar Pradesh under s. 4 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined in ,this appeal by the State of Uttar Pradesh, is whether the right of the respondent to receive the allowance under the arrangement of the year 1838 was extinguished as a consequence ensuing from the vesting of the Sudpore Bhettree parganas in the State of Uttar Pradesh under s. 4 of the Act.

issues.text: whether the allowance paid to the respondent could be regarded as an estate within the meaning of s. 3(8) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld the contention of the respondent that allowance paid to him could not be regarded as an estate. That view is not challenged before this Court by counsel for the State of Uttar Pradesh.

issues.text: whether the remission of revenue in respect of the 12 mahals is a right or privilege in respect of land revenue under s. 6(b) which determines upon vesting

anchor.surface_text: But of the 12 mahals the respondent was a proprietor the land of the mahals was estate within the meaning of s. 3(8) of the Act and by S. 4, the right of the respondent in that estate stood vested in and transferred to the State.

issues.text: whether the allowance granted as consideration for abandonment of rights to the 166 mahals is a right or privilege in respect of land or land revenue under s. 6(b)

arguments.claim: estate defined as area in registers under s.3(8); allowance not recorded as such

anchor.surface_text: By s.3(8) which was retrospectively amended by Act 14 of 1958, estate was defined as meaning the area included under one entry in any of the registers

holdings.text: The allowance paid to the respondent could not be regarded as an estate within the meaning of s. 3(8) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld the contention of the respondent that allowance paid to him could not be regarded as an estate. That view is not challenged before this Court by counsel for the State of Uttar Pradesh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allowance not recorded as an area in revenue registers under s.3(8); High Court view accepted and not challenged by State.

holdings.text: The land of the 12 mahals was an estate under s.3(8); rights vested under s.4; remission of land revenue is a right or privilege in respect of land revenue under s.6(b) which determines upon vesting.

anchor.surface_text: But of the 12 mahals the respondent was a proprietor the land of the mahals was estate within the meaning of s. 3(8) of the Act and by S. 4, the right of the respondent in that estate stood vested in and transferred to the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 12 mahals recorded as estate; remission directly linked to reducing payable revenue; vesting transfers estate rights and triggers s.6(b) determination; cannot convert to positive payment post-extinction.

holdings.text: The allowance for 166 mahals granted as consideration for abandonment of rights is not a right or privilege in respect of land or land revenue under s.6(b).

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the respondent in respect of the allowance granted as consideration for abandonment of the right to 166 mahals rests on a firmer ground. It is true that this allowance ,as computed as 1/4th share of the revenue assessed on the 166 mahals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No interest in land/revenue post-arrangement; allowance substitutes prior claim, measured by revenue quantum but lacks direct 'in respect of' connection required by s.6(b).

holdings.text: Absence of provision for compensation for such allowance indicates the right was not intended to be acquired or extinguished by the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Absence of a provision in the Act for payment of compensation for a right such as the one claimed by the respondent strongly supports the plea that the right is not intended to be acquired or extinguished.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed compensation machinery in ss.37-45 for acquired intermediary rights; omission for unrecorded allowances like this supports non-extinction.

holdings.text: Section 45 is a machinery provision for compensation computation and does not extend the acquisition or consequences under s.6 to unrecorded rights like the allowance.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 45, in computing the gross assets and net assets of proprietors who are assignees of land revenue whose names are recorded in the record of rights, maintained under cls. a to d of s.32

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies only to recorded assignees under specific registers; respondent not qualifying; cannot imply new extinctions without compensation.

holdings.text: High Court order confirmed for allowance of Rs.30,612-13-0 re 166 mahals but modified to dismiss claim for remission re 12 mahals; right partly extinguished under s.4 and s.6(b).

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the High Court was right in granting the application preferred by the respondent insofar as it related to the allowance of Rs. 30,612-13-0 granted as a consideration for extinction of the right of Harnarain Singh to 166 mahals but for reasons already stated,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes remission (extinguished) from substitute allowance (survives); applies vesting and s.6(b) differentially to facts of 12 vs 166 mahals.

justification_sets.label: U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951 Section 3(8) - Estate support
U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951 Section 6(b) support
U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951 Section 6(b) support
U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951 Preamble support
U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951 Section 6(b) support

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the High Court was right in granting the application preferred by the respondent insofar as it related to the allowance of Rs. 30,612-13-0 granted as a consideration for extinction of the right of Harnarain Singh to 166 mahals but for reasons already stated, we are unable to agree with the High Court that the respondent was entitled to receive in respect of the 12 mahals the land revenue which was remitted.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order modified: confirmed respondent's entitlement to allowance of Rs. 30,612-13-0 pertaining to 166 mahals; petition dismissed insofar as remission of land revenue on 12 mahals
directions: The order of the High Court in respect of the allowance of Rs. 30,612-13-0 will stand confirmed
The petition of the respondent in so far as it deals with remission of land revenue in respect of the 12 mahals of Syudpore Bhettree will stand dismissed
